docs.title: Background
docs.text:
Welcome to Elliptic Curves 101. The content for this section of The Number Line site was originally taken from: The Case for Curves: Unraveling Elliptic Curves. This material was the output of Nicholas Gledhill's research project, supervised by Dr. Jelena Schmalz at the University of New England (UNE), specifically for the unit SCI395 - Science Report.

The material has been copied here (and not simply linked to) so that it can be updated and improved over time, without the requirement to edit the original site. We will be updating the information here, to ensure it is as clear and helpful as possible.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Elliptic curves are a cornerstone of modern cryptographic systems. They have applications in, and generate interest in, many areas of:

  • Number Theory
  • Algebraic and Arithmetic Geometry
  • Complex Analysis
  • Topology
  • Dynamical (Chaotic) Systems

docs.title: Platforms & Tools Used
docs.text:
• MkDocs – A static site generator that converts Markdown files into a structured documentation website.
  • Material for MkDocs – A highly customizable theme that enhances MkDocs with modern UI features and improved styling.
  • Python – Used for running MkDocs and managing dependencies.
  • pip – Python’s package manager, used to install MkDocs and its dependencies.
  • KaTeX – A fast math typesetting library used to render mathematical expressions in Markdown.
  • GitHub – Version control and repository hosting for tracking changes and collaboration.
  • GitHub Pages – Free static site hosting for this project.
  • Desmos – Used for interactive mathematical visualizations and graphing.
  • Cloudflare (if applicable) – Provides security, performance optimization, and CDN caching for the site.

docs.title: The Additive Inverse on an Elliptic Curve
Definition of the Additive Inverse
docs.text:
For every point P on an Elliptic Curve, there exists a point P' (often denoted -P) such that: $$ P + P' = P + (-P) = P - P = \mathscr{O} $$

where \mathscr{O} is the point at infinity.

Your browser does not support the video tag.

docs.title: The Inverse of the Inverse
docs.text: Clearly, the opposite applies. That is: $$ -(-P) = P $$

docs.title: Characteristic of 2 and 3
docs.text: It should also be noted that an Elliptic Curve defined on any field with characteristic other than 2 or 3 can be converted into the Weierstrass form.

docs.title: Weierstrass Form and Symmetry Around the X-Axis
Equation of the Elliptic Curve in Weierstrass Form
docs.text:
The graph of an elliptic curve in Weierstrass form (Washington, L. C., 2008, pp. 9-11, Section 2.1) is given by: $$ y^2 = x^3 + Ax + B $$

where A and B are constants.

This equation exhibits symmetry across the x-axis due to several inherent properties.

docs.title: 1. Equation Form
docs.text:
The equation: $$ y^2 = x^3 + Ax + B $$

naturally defines symmetry about the x-axis because if (x,y) is a point on the curve, then (x,-y) must also be a point.

Since y^2 remains the same whether y or -y is used, this ensures symmetry.

docs.title: 2. Even Function Relationship
docs.text:
The function y = x^2 is an even function, meaning its graph is symmetric with respect to the y-axis.

For an elliptic curve, if you "swap" x and y in y = x^2 , you obtain: $$ y^2 = f(x) $$

which represents an elliptic curve when f(x) is a cubic function.

docs.title: 3. Geometric Interpretation
docs.text:
Geometrically, this symmetry means that:

  • The curve mirrors itself across the x-axis.
  • Any vertical line at a given x value intersects the curve at two points that are equidistant from the x-axis but on opposite sides.

docs.title: The Role of Symmetry in Group Structure
docs.text:
Symmetry plays a critical role in the group law for elliptic curves:

  1. Point Addition and the Inverse

  2. The inverse of a point (x, y) is (x, -y) .

  3. This ensures that the curve forms an abelian group.

  4. Conversion to Weierstrass Form

  5. Any elliptic curve with characteristic other than 2 or 3 can be converted to Weierstrass form.
  6. This allows us to use the symmetry of the Weierstrass equation for most investigations.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
The x-axis symmetry in the Weierstrass equation is a direct consequence of:

  • The algebraic structure of the equation.
  • The fact that y^2 is always positive.
  • The group law, which ensures that (x, y) and (x, -y) always exist in the curve’s structure.

docs.title: More General Forms of an Elliptic Curve
docs.text:
Less obviously, the inverse by vertical line projection also applies to some more general equations for elliptic curves.

A general form of an elliptic curve is: $$ y^2 + a_1xy + a_3y = x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_4x + a_6 $$

(Washington, L. C., 2008, p. 10, Equation 2.1) where a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4, a_6 are constants.

docs.title: Computing the Inverse in General Form
docs.text:
Given a point P = (x,y) , the inverse -P is: $$ -P = (x, -y - a_1x - a_3) $$

This adjustment accounts for linear terms in y but still defines a point vertically adjacent to P .

docs.title: Exploring Transformations
docs.text:
Your browser does not support the video tag.

In the animation above:

  • A and B remain constant.

  • All versions of the elliptic curve can be converted into Weierstrass form: $$ y^2 = x^3 + Ax + B $$

  • The values are transformed as follows: $$ x_{\text{new}} = dx + f $$

$$ y_{\text{new}} = ax_{\text{new}} + by + c $$

The animation explores what happens to the general transformed equation when altering the values of:

  • d, f, a, b, c while keeping:
  • A, B , and the initial P and Q (and therefore R and R' = -R ) unchanged.

docs.title: The Discrete Logarithm Problem
docs.text: The Discrete Logarithm Problem is a foundational problem in the field of cryptography and number theory.

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
The Discrete Logarithm Problem involves finding an integer x given the equation: $$ g^x \equiv h \mod p $$

where:

  • g is a known base
  • h is a known result
  • p is a prime number (or the order of the group in more general settings)

In reference to the idea of operations on sets of elements, the operation: $$ g^h $$

refers to applying the operation (in this case, multiplication *) h times. That is: $$ g^h = g \times g \times g \times \dots \times g \quad \text{(h times)} $$

In the case of elliptic curves, we often refer to the same problem, in terms of the + operation: $$ gh = h + h + h + \dots + h \quad \text{(h times)} $$

But the complexity of reversing the operation is still referred to as the Discrete Logarithm Problem.

docs.title: Group Theory
docs.text: The problem is defined within the context of cyclic groups, where the operations are performed under modular arithmetic.

docs.title: Cryptography
docs.text:
The Discrete Logarithm Problem is crucial in the security of cryptographic protocols, particularly in public key cryptography, such as:

  • Diffie-Hellman key exchange
  • Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC)

docs.title: Difficulty
docs.text:
The "discrete" part of the name emphasises that this problem is concerned with integers, unlike its continuous counterpart in real numbers.

The complexity of finding k in the equation: $$ kP \equiv Q $$

(for multiplication on an elliptic curve) is what makes it valuable for cryptography.

There are no known efficient (polynomial time) algorithms for solving it in general cases, making it a computationally hard problem.

For applications in cryptography, we seek groups where the Discrete Logarithm Problem is computationally difficult to solve.

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
The difficulty of the Discrete Logarithm Problem underpins the security of various encryption systems and digital signatures, where:

  • It is easy to compute exponentiation.
  • It is hard to reverse (i.e., compute the logarithm).
  • This provides cryptographic security.

docs.title: Further Study
docs.text:
For an interesting investigation of the algebra behind the Discrete Logarithm Problem, and its importance in Applied Cryptography, check out:

🔗 Leandro Junes' YouTube playlist: The Discrete Logarithm Problem

docs.title: Elliptic Curves over  \mathbb{R}
docs.text: Elliptic curves have applications in various mathematical fields, including number theory and cryptography.

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
An elliptic curve over \mathbb{R} is defined by a cubic equation of the form: $$ y^2 = x^3 + Ax + B $$

where A and B are real coefficients.

When these coefficients satisfy the condition: $$ 4A^3 + 27B^2 \neq 0 $$

the curve is non-singular.

Elliptic curves that do not satisfy this condition are called singular elliptic curves.

docs.title: The Weierstrass Equation
docs.text:
In the form: $$ y^2 = x^3 + Ax + B $$

an elliptic curve is said to be in the Weierstrass Equation form.

There are more general equations that define elliptic curves over \mathbb{R} (Washington, L. C., 2008, pp. 35-42, Section 2.5). However, elliptic curves can be converted into the Weierstrass Equation form when defined across fields with a characteristic other than 2 or 3.

docs.title: Animation of ECs in the Weierstrass form
docs.text:
See below, an animation of different elliptic curves in the Weierstrass Form, for varying values of the coefficients A and B (in the equation y^2 = x^3 + Ax + B ):

Your browser does not support the video tag.

docs.title: Discriminant and Shape
docs.text:
The shape of an elliptic curve in Weierstrass form depends on the discriminant: $$ \Delta = -16(4A^3 + 27B^2) $$

(Washington, L. C., 2008, pp. 9-11, Section 2.1)

  • If \Delta < 0 , the curve is a single, connected loop. The cubic equation: x^3 + Ax + B = 0 has one real solution.

  • If \Delta > 0 , the curve consists of two disjoint loops. The cubic equation: x^3 + Ax + B = 0 has three real solutions.

Note: The definition of these "loops" will become clearer once we introduce the concept of the point at infinity. For now, we accept that the far end of each curve connects at infinity.

docs.title: Symmetry
docs.text: Every elliptic curve in Weierstrass form is symmetric about the x-axis. If (x, y) is on the curve, then so is (x, -y) .

docs.title: Group Law: Addition of Points
docs.text:
Elliptic curves over \mathbb{R} form a group under the operation of point addition.

If P and Q are points on the curve, their sum P + Q is defined geometrically by:

  • Drawing a line through P and Q .
  • Finding its third intersection point with the curve.
  • Reflecting that point over the x-axis.

docs.title: When  P = Q
docs.text:
When P = Q (i.e the points you are adding together are equal), as described above under "Group Law": $$ P + Q = 2P $$

so the equation for the gradient: $$ m = \frac{ y_Q - y_P }{ x_Q - x_P } $$

no longer makes any sense - because: $$ x_Q - x_P = 0 $$

and therefore, the denominator would be 0.

So we need to find the slope of E: $$ m = \frac{ x_P^2 + a }{ 2 y_P } $$

(Washington, L. C., 2008, pp13-14, Section 2.2)

The concept of finding the slope of an Elliptic Curve will be further explored in the section on "Formal Derivatives". For now, we will simply say that we use the derivative for finding the slope at a point on the curve.

docs.title: When  y = 0
docs.text:
That is: the tangent to the curve E is a vertical line.

So: $$ 2P = \text{"the point at infinity"} $$

It can also be shown, related to the definition of addition for elliptic curves, that any straight line that passes through 3 point on the curve ( P , Q and R ) represents the fact that: $$ P + Q + R = 0 $$

For this, and many related reasons, the "point at infinity" is taken to be the "additive neutral element" for the Group defined for Elliptic Curves (Washington, Section 2.3, pp18-20).

NOTE: When defined in \mathbb{R} , it can easily be shown that, if the tangent line to the curve E is anything other than vertical, it will intersect with E (in the Affine plane), at another point.

docs.title: Cryptography
docs.text: Elliptic curves over \mathbb{R} serve as simpler models for understanding more complex cryptographic schemes over finite fields and rings, including those used in Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC).

docs.title: Theoretical Mathematics
docs.text: Elliptic curves are studied for their properties in algebraic geometry and number theory.

docs.title: Visualisation
docs.text: Unlike elliptic curves over finite fields (used in cryptography), curves over \mathbb{R} can be graphically represented, making visual learning more intuitive.

docs.title: Complexity in Handling
docs.text:
While real-number elliptic curves are easier to visualise, they introduce complexities in ensuring mathematical rigor, especially concerning:

  • Limits
  • Continuity
  • Differentiability

docs.title: Adding and Doubling Points: P, 2P, 3P, 4P, 8P, etc.
docs.text: Adding and doubling points is an essential element of the algebra of Elliptic Curves.

docs.title: Adding Points on an Elliptic Curve
docs.text:
Adding points involves joining the point P to the point Q and finding the point R where the line between P and Q intersects the elliptic curve E .

As discussed earlier, if the line that passes through P and Q is not vertical, that line is guaranteed to pass through one other point on the elliptic curve, in the affine plane.

docs.title: Doubling a Point (Finding 2P)
docs.text:
Finding 2P involves taking the tangent line to the curve at P . This corresponds to the case where: $$ P + Q = P + P = 2P $$

If P and Q are the same point ( P = Q ), the line becomes a tangent to the curve. Again, if the tangent is not vertical, it will intersect another point on the elliptic curve, in the affine plane.

Adding points repeatedly allows you to find: $$ P, 2P, 3P, 4P, \dots $$

The process follows this pattern:

  1. Find the tangent to the curve at P .
  2. Locate the second intersection of that tangent with the curve.
  3. Reflect that intersection point over the x-axis to find 2P .
  4. Find the line passing through P and 2P , locate the intersection, reflect, and get 3P .
  5. Repeat the process to compute higher multiples 4P, 5P, \dots .

docs.title: 📽 Animation: Adding Points
docs.text:
🎞 See the animation below for different values of P, 2P, 3P, and 4P for various starting values of P .

Your browser does not support the video tag.

One interesting moment to notice, in this animation, is the instant where:

P = -2P = 4P

around timecodes 0:44 and 1:58.

This point is also the inflection point on the curve where the curve shifts from -ve curvature +ve curvature - which allows a point to be drawn through P (at this exact point) that only intersect the curve once, in such a way that represents a "triple root". That is:

3 P = \mathscr{O}

and so:

2P = - P \leadsto P = - 2P \leadsto P = 4P

docs.title: Repeated Doubling (2P, 4P, 8P, ...)
docs.text:
Doubling a point repeatedly requires taking the tangent to the curve at P .

  1. Compute 2P :

  2. Take the tangent at P .

  3. Find the intersection point and its reflection to get 2P .

  4. Compute 4P :

  5. Use 2P as the starting point.

  6. Take the tangent at 2P .

  7. Find the new intersection, reflect, and get 4P .

  8. Compute 8P :

  9. Use 4P .
  10. Take the tangent at 4P .
  11. Find the new intersection, reflect, and get 8P .

docs.title: The Point at Infinity
docs.text: The point at infinity on an elliptic curve is the identity element of the curve's group structure, serving as the neutral element for point addition.

docs.title: Group Identity Property
docs.text:
For any point P : $$ P + \mathscr{O} = P $$

where \mathscr{O} is the point at infinity. $$ P + (-P) = P - P = \mathscr{O} $$

docs.title: Torsion Points
docs.text: Torsion points on elliptic curves are special points that have a finite order.

docs.title: Definition of Torsion Points
docs.text:
A point P on an elliptic curve is a torsion point if there exists a positive integer n such that: $$ nP = \mathscr{O} $$

where:

  • P is a point on the curve.
  • nP represents adding P to itself n times.
  • \mathscr{O} is the identity element (the point at infinity).

Note: the inflection point, mentioned above, where: $$ 3P = \mathscr{O} $$

is one of these Torsion Points.

docs.title: Properties of Torsion Points
docs.text:
• Finite Order: Torsion points have finite order, meaning that for some smallest integer n , the repeated addition of P leads to the point at infinity.

  • Subgroup Structure: The set of all torsion points on an elliptic curve forms a subgroup, known as the torsion subgroup of the curve.

docs.title: Examples of Torsion Points
docs.text:
• 6P = \mathscr{O} → The point at infinity.
  • 16P = \mathscr{O} → The point at infinity.

docs.title: Torsion Points in Finite Fields
docs.text: Torsion points play a key role in cryptography, especially in elliptic curve cryptosystems. The security of these systems often relies on the size and structure of the torsion subgroup.

docs.title: Theorem Application: Mazur’s Torsion Theorem
docs.text:
The Mazur’s Torsion Theorem (see as well [1], and [2]) provides a remarkable result about the torsion subgroups of elliptic curves over \mathbb{Q} (the rational numbers).

It states that the torsion subgroup of any elliptic curve over \mathbb{Q} is isomorphic to one of fifteen possible groups, which are either:

  • Cyclic groups of order n for n = 1 to 10 , or 12 .
  • Products of two cyclic groups with specific orders.

Torsion points remain a key area of research in number theory and algebraic geometry, providing insights into:

  • The structure of elliptic curves.
  • Applications in algorithms and cryptography.

docs.title: What is a Set, a Group, a Ring, and a Field?
Set
docs.text:
A set is a collection of distinct objects, considered as an object in its own right. These objects are called the elements or members of the set.

More on sets - Wolfram MathWorld

docs.title: Group
docs.text:
A group is a set equipped with an operation that combines any two elements to form a third element (which also must belong to the set) in such a way that it is:

  • Associative
  • Has an identity element
  • Every element has an inverse with repect to a given operation

More on groups - Wolfram MathWorld

docs.title: Associative Property
docs.text:
An operation is "associative" if changing the grouping of the operands does not change the result. If the operation is denoted by *, then for any elements a, b, c: $$ (a \ast b) \ast c = a \ast (b \ast c) $$

always holds.

docs.title: Identity Element
docs.text:
An identity element is an element in a set that, when combined with any other element of the set through a specific binary operation, leaves the other element unchanged.

For a binary operation * defined on a set S , an element e \in S is an identity element if, for every element a \in S : $$ e_a = a \quad \text{and} \quad a_e = a $$

Common examples include:

  • 0 for addition
  • 1 for multiplication

docs.title: Inverse Element
docs.text:
An inverse under a particular binary operation is an element that, when combined with another element, results in the identity element.

For an operation * defined on a set, if e is the identity element, then for any element a in the set, an element b (often denoted as a^{-1} ) is called the inverse of a if: $$ a \ast b = e \quad \text{and} \quad b \ast a = e $$

Common examples:

  • Additive inverse: a + (-a) = 0
  • Multiplicative inverse: a \times a^{-1} = 1

docs.title: Abelian Group
docs.text:
An abelian group is a group in which the group operation is also commutative (as well as associative). "Commutative" means that the order in which two elements are combined does not affect the result: $$ a \ast b = b \ast a $$

More on abelian groups - Wolfram MathWorld

docs.title: Commutative Property
docs.text:
An operation is commutative if: $$ a \ast b = b \ast a $$

for all elements a, b in the set.

docs.title: Ring
docs.text:
A ring is a set equipped with two binary operations (usually referred to as addition and multiplication) where:

  • Addition forms a group
  • Multiplication is associative
  • The distributive property holds over addition

More on rings - Wolfram MathWorld

docs.title: Key Properties of a Ring
docs.text:
For all a, b, c \in R :

  • Closure under addition and multiplication: a + b \in R and a \times b \in R
  • Associativity of addition and multiplication: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c), \quad (a \times b) \times c = a \times (b \times c)
  • Commutativity of addition: a + b = b + a
  • Existence of an additive identity: There exists 0 \in R such that a + 0 = a
  • Existence of additive inverses: For every a \in R , there exists -a \in R such that a + (-a) = 0
  • Distributive laws: a \times (b + c) = a \times b + a \times c

docs.title: Optional Properties:
docs.text:
• Multiplicative identity: In some definitions, particularly for rings that are also termed unital or unitary, there exists an element 1 \in R (distinct from 0) such that a \ast 1 = a and 1 \ast a = 1 for all a \in R
  • Commutativity of multiplication: In a commutative ring, for all a, b \in R , a \ast b = b \ast a . However, this property is not required for a set to be a ring. Without this property, the set is called a "non-commutative ring" If satisfied, the ring is called a "commutative ring".

docs.title: Field
docs.text:
A field is a set equipped with two binary operations (addition and multiplication) that satisfy:

  • Closure: a + b \in F , a \times b \in F (Wolfram MathWorld)
  • Associativity: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c) and (a \times b) \times c = a \times (b \times c) (Wolfram MathWorld)
  • Commutativity: a + b = b + a and a \times b = b \times a (Wolfram MathWorld)
  • Identity Elements:

  • There exists 0 such that a + 0 = a
  • There exists 1 such that a \times 1 = a
  • (Wolfram MathWorld
  • Additive Inverses: For every a , there exists -a such that a + (-a) = 0 (Wolfram MathWorld)
  • Multiplicative Inverses: For every nonzero a , there exists a^{-1} such that: a \times a^{-1} = 1 (Wolfram MathWorld)
  • Distributivity: a \times (b + c) = (a \times b) + (a \times c) (Wolfram MathWorld)

More on fields - Wolfram MathWorld

docs.title: Relationship to Rings
docs.text:
A field is a ring in which:

  • Every nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse.
  • Multiplication is commutative.

docs.title: Abstract Algebra
docs.text:
Abstract algebra is a branch of mathematics that studies algebraic structures such as groups, rings, and fields. These structures form the backbone of various mathematical disciplines, including:

  • Number Theory
  • Topology
  • Algebraic Geometry

Abstract algebra explores deep relationships between these structures using axioms such as associativity, commutativity, and inverses. This field is fundamental to both theoretical and applied mathematics, particularly in solving polynomial equations, understanding symmetry, and developing modern cryptographic systems.

docs.title: Theorem / Proof: A Line Connecting P and Q Always Intersects a Third Point
Introduction
docs.text: How do we know that a line connecting P and Q will always intersect another point on the curve? This fundamental property allows us to define a Group Law for an Elliptic Curve over a given Field.

docs.title: Considering the Affine Plane
docs.text:
There are more succinct theorems that take into account the point at infinity in elliptic curves. These theorems can also discuss vertical lines (where x_P = x_Q when P and Q are distinct).

However, at this stage in our study of elliptic curves, it is more informative to consider the case strictly within the affine plane - without introducing the point at infinity or the projective plane. This allows us to explore how far we can take this definition within that construct.

docs.title: Key Observations
docs.text:
By avoiding the concept of the point at infinity, we encounter the following limitations:

  1. Not all points on the curve form a strict group in the affine plane

  2. Some points, when added, do not exist in the field on which the curve is defined.

  3. Not all points have an additive inverse

  4. Without the point at infinity, some necessary group properties are missing.

Understanding the difference between an elliptic curve defined on the affine plane and one that includes the point at infinity is essential for grasping why the point at infinity is considered the additive neutral element of the group.

docs.title: Simplified Approach
docs.text:
For now, we simplify the discussion by ignoring cases where the slope of the line between two points on the curve is vertical.

docs.text:
